review.title: Warranty Cost Estimation Using Bayesian Network
review.abstract: All multi-component product manufacturing companies face the problem of warranty cost estimation. Failure rate analysis of components plays a key role in this problem. Data source used for failure rate analysis has traditionally been past failure data of components. However, failure rate analysis can be improved by means of fusion of additional information, such as symptoms observed during after-sale service of the product, geographical information (hilly or plains areas), and information from tele-diagnostic analytics. In this paper, we propose an approach, which learns dependency between part-failures and symptoms gleaned from such diverse sources of information, to predict expected number of failures with better accuracy. We also indicate how the optimum warranty period can be computed. We demonstrate, through empirical results, that our method can improve the warranty cost estimates significantly.

metadata.title: Warranty Cost Estimation Using Bayesian Networks

sections.heading: 1 Introduction and Motivation
sections.text: In fact, we will be able to get to grips with the problems of the past.

sections.heading: 1.1 Overview
sections.text: To get an overview of our approach, we need to address the question of whether we will be able to find a solution that meets people's needs.

sections.heading: 2 Data Description
sections.text: We consider data for the duration t1 to t2 for n products indexed from 1 to n, with each product having m parts. Data is obtained from three sources: data on the failure of a part, service records and telediagnosis data. Data sets from the three sources are: • Data on the failure of a part: data on the failure of a part we have a variable pj, i: number of cycles in which a part Pj fails in the ith product, where i-1, 2,..., n} and j-1, 2,..., m}. These cycles can be time to failure (hours, days, seconds) for a product, miles for which a vehicle is driven, etc. • Data on the occurrence of the DTC: We assume that each part Pj is associated with a series of DTCs s.t. Pj ← {Dj, 1, Dj, 2, seconds) for a product.

sections.heading: 2.1 Definitions
sections.text: • Cj: This sentence contains index of products in which part Pj fails for the first time in the time interval [t1, t2], in which j = 1 to m.Cj = {i: index of a product in which part Pj fails in the time interval [t1, t2]. Leave the cardinality of the sentence Cj is nj, i.e., | Cj | = nj, in which 1 ≤ nj ′ n. • Failj: This sentence contains number of cycles in which part Pj fails for each product in Cj. Failj = {pj, i: i, Cj}, | Failj | = nj} (1) • Indj, k: This sentence contains number of cycles in which part Pj, k associated with part Pj occurs for the first time in Cj. Failj = {pj, i, k: This sentence Indj, k: in each product in Cj.

sections.heading: 3 Background
sections.text: In this section, we will give an introduction to Bayesian networks and how parameters can be learned using Bayesian networks. In the next section, we will introduce our Bayesian network, which is used to learn the dependence between partial failure and DTCs. A Bayesian network is a representation of the common probability distribution. This representation consists of two components. The first component G is a directed acyclic graph whose vertices correspond to the random variables X1, X2,..., Xn. The second component describes a conditional distribution for each variable in relation to its parent G. Together, these two components give a unique distribution to X1, X2,..., Xn. Graph G encodes the assumption of independence by which the Xi variable is independent of its non-descendants, since its parents in G [1], [8].By applying the chain rule of probabilities and properties of conditional independence and the common probability distribution, which Marcov assumptions fulfill, the Xyesian network can not be classified as the Xyesian network (Xyesip) structure (Xyesip).

sections.heading: 4 Modeling Dependence Using Bayesian Networks
sections.text: As discussed in Section 1, the Bayesian network is used in Fig. 1 to explain the dependence between the part DTC and the part DTC. It follows as the leading indicators of the part DTC. We assume that each part Pj and its associated DTC Dj, k have some dependencies. Our goal is to learn the dependence between Dj, k and Pj, k always, approximately two months before the part failure Pk, 2) DTC Dj, k occurring before the actual part Pk failure, the following probability distribution. Our goal is to learn the dependence between Dj, k and Pj, j, j and k = 1 to r.The Bayesian networks combine the Bayesian probability theory and the concept of conditional independence to represent dependencies between variables [20]. In this section, we present a Bayesian network that can learn the dependencies or patterns between the part of failure and the associated DTC.

sections.heading: 4.1 Learning Parameters of Bayesian Network
sections.text: Dependencies between the part Pj and its corresponding DTC Dj, k i.e. dependencies between Fj, Ij, k and Sj, k can be recorded by the learning parameters Rj, k, σ 1 j, k, Mj, k, σ 2 j, k in our Bayesian network (Fig. 1). The scale and shape parameters βj and αj for the part Pj are used to determine the expected number of errors (explained in 5.1). We learn these parameters using the method of the MCMC [7] implemented by the Metropolis Hastings algorithm [10].

sections.heading: 5 Failure Rate Analysis Using Bayesian Networks
sections.text: In this section, we first introduce an approach to calculating the expected number of errors based on the scale and shape parameters of the Weibull distribution. Later in this section, we introduce the detailed approach to calculating error rate parameters based on the Bayean network, which is described in Section 4.

sections.heading: 5.1 Expected Number of Failures
sections.text: Assuming that each part follows Pj error, the Weibull distribution follows with form parameters as αj and scale parameters as βj. Taking into account the scale and form parameters, we can calculate the expected number of errors of the part Pj-j = 1 to m. The expected number of errors for n cars (each car has m parts) in the time interval t3 to t4 is derived from the equation = n ∑ i = 1 m ² j = 1 Fj (T) (17), where Fj (T) is the probability that the part will fail in the time interval t3 to t4.

sections.heading: 5.2 Expected Number of Failures Using Bayesian Networks
sections.text: In this section, we will only use partial failure data to analyze the failure rate; in the second case, we will use partial failure data and service records; and in the third case, we will use partial failure data and sensor data to analyze failure rates; in the first case, we will only use partial failure data to analyze the failure rate; and in the second case, we will use partial failure data and service records to analyze failure rates.

sections.heading: 5.3 Warranty Cost Estimation
sections.text: The warranty costs are the product of the cost of spare parts and the estimated loss during the warranty period. However, there are other costs incurred by the company in relation to customer dissatisfaction, which are referred to as penalty costs. These penalty costs relate to the parts that fail after the warranty period and decrease over time. Thus, the warranty costs Cj for the third part with the warranty period are given as wj below. Cj = RjF (wj) + Rjbe − cwj (1 − F (wj))) (20), with b, c > 0 R, F (wj) corresponding to a fraction of the parts that fail before wj and Rj being the replacement costs for the part Pj. The optimal warranty period, which minimizes the total cost Cj, can easily be calculated by the method of gradient decrease [6] for any specified values of b, c in eq 20.

sections.heading: 6 Experiment and Results
sections.text: In this section, we will present a comparison of the expected number of failures for the three cases described in Section 5.2 on simulated vehicle data. We will simulate data corresponding to a component failure, sensor data and service records. We will first describe the three simulated data sets and then present the comparison of three cases (discussed in Section 5.2 on these data sets). We will also present the results of the optimal warranty period (discussed in Section 5.3) We used the Python module PYMC [9] to learn the dependency parameters of the Bayesian network. We will use the learned parameters to predict the number of future component failures.

sections.heading: 6.1 Simulated datasets
sections.text: We simulated data for 1000 cars in which each car has nine parts. We have cars manufactured over three years 2010, 2011 and 2012. Data for the period from January 1, 2010 to December 31, 2012 are used to learn the dependency parameters of the Baja network, and the learned parameters are then used to predict the number of partial failures in 2013. Simulation data for partial failure data, sensor data and service logs are as follows: Partial failure data: In order to generate partial failure data, we assume that the number of miles preceding the failure of a part of Pj follows the Weibull distribution with form and scale parameters αj or βj, where j-data {1, 2,..., 9}. Number of miles where Pj fails is generated using an inverse transformation method [11].

sections.heading: 6.2 Observations and Results
sections.text: In this section, we compare the results of three cases discussed in Section 5.2. We also compare the results with the Best Scenario, where we use the same approach to find the expected number of errors as explained in Case 3, except that we compare Step 1 of Case 3. Also, in Step 2, instead of predicting the errors we make, we form the Fail ′ j sentence with the actual number of future errors as represented in the simulated data. Steps 3 and 4 are the same as in Case 3. Best Scenario assumes that our Bayesian network model can predict the actual number of miles for each error. In Figure 5, the first column lists the names of nine parts. In Actual Parameters column, we have shown the scale and shape parameters used to simulate partial failure data for each part. We compare these actual parameters with the parameters we learned from our model, using three different approaches in Case 2 and Section 6.

sections.heading: 7 Related Work
sections.text: There are many studies that use statistical methods to integrate data sets from different sources, using the interaction and correlation between them to obtain more refined information. In [17], a common probability model is used to combine gene expression and upstream sequence data to find significant gene clusters. Similarly, in [18], we propose a model for merging data from multiple sources such as partial failure data, telediagnostic data, service records using an approach based on the Bayesian network that can learn conditional dependence on symptom data at partial failure rate, leading to an improvement in the predictability of warranty costs. We also support our claims with empirical results based on simulated data inspired by real data. Bayesian network has predicted many real-world applications [15]. In [8] Bayesian network, we will use better prediction of heart failure components [14].

sections.heading: 8 Conclusion and Future Work
sections.text: We have also described how our approach learns the dependencies of symptoms derived from different sources of information about the actual failure rate of parts. We have also shown that predicting future failures using these dependencies can contribute to a better estimation of warranty costs. We have tested our approach using simulated data for vehicles that have data on past partial failures and data from gas stations and telediagnosis. We have shown that our approach can capture the information provided by leading indicators and predict future failures with better accuracy. In addition, our estimation of partial failures from symptom data by comparing it to the best-case scenario is almost identical to actual partial failures. Therefore, we conclude that error rate analysis can be improved using service records and sensor data, using our predictive data as a basis. In the future, we plan to expand the proposed model by using more information than actual information such as geographic areas or seasonal variations to predict current costs.

Data source used for failure rate analysis has traditionally been past failure data of components. In this paper, we propose an approach, which learns dependency between part-failures and symptoms gleaned from such diverse sources of information, to predict expected number of failures with better accuracy. We also indicate how the optimum warranty period can be computed. We demonstrate, through empirical results, that our method can improve the warranty cost estimates significantly.
